Yes, there have been instances where Iceland's volcanic activity has caused long-term environmental effects. 

For example, the 2014 eruption of Bárðarbunga, which took place over six months, created a 50-square-kilometer lava field and released sulfur dioxide and other gases into the atmosphere. These poisonous gases can contribute to acid rain and reduce air quality, which can have significant impacts on the environment and human health.

In addition, volcanic activity can alter the landscape and soil composition, which can have long-term effects on agriculture and vegetation. The 1783 Laki eruption, which lasted eight months, released vast amounts of ash and gases and is estimated to have killed over 50% of Iceland's livestock and 25% of its human population due to famine and disease caused by the eruption.

Overall, while Iceland's volcanic activity is a vital natural resource and an essential part of the country's unique environment, it is also a significant hazard that requires careful management and monitoring to prevent or mitigate long-term environmental effects.
